Bhagavat Gita the ultimate guide to proper living, tells us how we should speak. ‘Anudvegaram, sathyam, priya-hitham vakhyam’ XVII-15: speech that causes no annoyance, truthful, loving and beneficial. It emphasises self-control – ‘a wandering mind carries away reason, much the same way gale blows away a ship on the ocean’, II-67. In particular, Gita, points to ‘kama and kroda’, lust and anger, as our greatest enemies, III-37. Meditation, sustained and regular, is the surest way to help achieve self-control. Observing regular mouna vritham is another way of improving one’s self-control and being able to speak properly and wisely. Mahatma Gandhi used to practise it regularly. Kanchi Mahaswamigal used to observe, not just mauna vratam, but, kasta mauna vratam, where he did not even communicate through hand signals on chosen days!

As we are entering the Tamil month of Maasi, it may be useful to remind ourselves that during Maasi, our forefathers used to practise mouna vritham on all Tuesdays. Might be, we can all try to observe mouna vritham at least for one hour on each maasi Tuesdays!

Maasi is significant for another reason. On the 13th night/14th day in the Krishna Paksham in the Tamil month of Maasi, Mahasivarathri is observed. This year, Mahasivarathri falls on Thursday, the 27th of February. It is not just a day for prayers, but, for fasting. Fasting is an important aspect of self-control.

No one explains the significance of Mahasivarathri with greater authority or clarity than Kanchi Mahaperiaval: do read what he said about Mahasivarathri in our website: You may also read another interesting article about Mahasivarathri by a SIS member, Mr. Rajja Rajagopalan

On Mahasivarathri day devotees fast and perform pooja to Lord Shiva and visit Shiva temples. Let’s all do Shiva Pooja on Shivarathri and get the blessings of Lord Shiva.

About the trainer:

Shyamala alias Sam is a self-motivated and passionate yoga instructor, who has been inspired by her guru Sri Asana Andiappan who practices and lives the yogic philosophies until today in his 80's.

She qualified as a Yoga therapist at the renowned Andiappan college of Yoga and research, Chennai, India, successfully completing an intensive Yoga Therapy course and basic principles of Ayurveda.

She is certified to instruct Yoga in corporate circles, community centres, sport and leisure and schools. She has developed her own style of teaching that combines Vinyasa and Ashtanga delivered with a touch of Iyengar Yoga making it suitable for all ability levels and those with particular health issues.

Sam has actively participated and volunteered to travel in her groups for yogic and meditation courses and workshops conducted in India, Malaysia and Thailand.
